body: “Only use the dirty water to shower,” said Florence Mandible. “And don’t forget that ever since inflation hit 48% and the US dollar became next to worthless on the global currency markets, things are pretty tight around here.” Her 12-year-old son, Willing, toyed with a .44 Colt that he had stolen from some Lat. Ever since the Mexicans took over the country and he was forced to speak Spanish at school, he had taken a keen interest in paramilitary survivalism, just like her brother Jarred who nobody ever mentioned. “Put that gun down and go and queue for some foodstuffs that will probably have gone off by the time you get home,” Florence said. She kind of missed the old days when the worst that seemed to happen was that a few bankers tried to fiddle the Libor rate. In Washington, Avery Mandible was anxious that all of her patients were cancelling their therapy sessions because tax rates had gone up to 88%, interest rates had hit a new high of minus 23% and the only people left in work were those making money off the influx of Chinese tourists. She decided to call her sister on her FleX watch. “Hi Florence,” she said. “I kinda just miss the stonage days of 2025 when the internet collapsed and no online financial transactions could be authorised. At least in those days a $50,000 bill still had some value.” “Me too, Avery,” Florence replied. “It sure is tough when US government borrowing has reached 290% of GDP.” “You shouldn’t worry too much,” said Avery. “My husband Lowell, the respected Georgetown economist, has modelled projections saying that even 385% is perfectly sustainable. Besides, we still have the backup of Grandpa Douglas’s millions. He’s now 95 and can’t live for ever.”   Related: The Mandibles: A Family, 2029-2047 by Lionel Shriver – a vibrant vision of America in decline    Both women’s FleX’s pinged. It was an alert from the US Treasury saying that everyone’s gold reserves were being nationalised and that even people’s teeth would be requisitioned by the army. “That means I am now also officially broke and can no longer care for my second wife, Luella, who is suffering from dementia,” said Grandpa Douglas. “So I will now have to go and live with my son Carter.” “Why can’t you go and live with my sister, Enola?” Carter said. “At least she has some money in the alternative currency of bancors.” “In case you had forgotten,” Grandpa Douglas responded, anxious to use a word different to replied, “bancors are a proscribed currency, and Enola lives in France.” “Well, you can’t live with me because now that the official annualised rate of inflation is now 215% I too am broke. We’ll all have to go and live with Lowell and Avery.”     Novelist Lionel Shriver. Photograph: Eamonn McCabe for the Guardian    “I’m afraid you can’t,” Lowell said grimly. “I’ve just been fired from my job, as unemployment has risen to 3,400%. We’re going to have to take our kids, Savannah, Goog and Bing, out of private schools and go and live with Florence in New York, where they will learn nothing with Lat kids.” “Guess what,” said Enola. “I’m fed up with nobody buying my novels in France so I am coming to live with Florence too.” Grandpa Douglas, demented Luella, Carter, Lowell, Avery, Savannah, Goog, Bing, Enola, Willing and Florence all sat miserably in Florence’s tenement flat, searching for scraps of cloth with which to wipe their bottoms, while lamenting the fact that they were the victims of a strict novelistic determinism that only allowed them to talk at length about the economic apocalypse. “I’ve got no money,” said Savannah. “I’m going to be a hooker.” “I’m going to steal stuff,” said Willing. “Does no one one have any redeeming qualities?” asked Bing. “No,” said Lionel. Just then a group of people took over the flat and forced Grandpa Douglas, demented Luella etc to go and live in a tent in the park. Grandpa Douglas shot demented Luella and then himself. Lucky Grandpa and demented Luella. 2047: “I’m not enjoying living in a world where the US is a third-world state, where tax rates are 98% and every transaction is controlled by a treasury implant in my head,” said Willing, who had just killed someone who had killed several dozen other people. “Well, I’ve still got a bit of cash stashed away,” said Enola. “Why don’t we drive to the breakaway United States of Nevada and see if we can find Jarred?” “To be honest, it’s not all it’s cracked up to be here either,” shrugged Jarred. Somehow, no one found that surprising. Digested read, digested: The Unreadables.
